feed.title: NewsTracker: fifa
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Former FIFA Official Banned From Soccer For Life
entry.summary:
GENEVA (AP) - Chuck Blazer was banned for life by FIFA's ethics committee on Thursday for widespread corruption, finally ending the career of the longtime most senior American in world football.

FIFA's ethics panel made its ruling using evidence from the American federal case which has plunged FIFA and international football into crisis.

The plot linked Blazer and two other then-FIFA executive committee members in getting cash which South African officials asked FIFA to transfer through the governing body's accounts in 2008.

FIFA opened an ethics investigation against Blazer after the corrupt financial management of CONCACAF was exposed in 2012.

entry.title: FIFA expels disgraced Blazer for life
entry.summary: FIFA's ethics panel says American Blazer "was a key player in schemes involving the offer, acceptance, payment and receipt of undisclosed and illegal payments, bribes and kickbacks as well as other money-making schemes."

entry.title: Disgraced Chuck Blazer given life ban from football by Fifa ethics committee
entry.summary: In a statement, Fifa's ethics panel said Blazer had "committed many and various acts of misconduct continuously and repeatedly during his time as an official in different high-ranking and influential positions at Fifa and Concacaf.

entry.title: Ben Affleck, Matt Damon to produce FIFA scandal movie
World Cup moments distanced women from FIFA scandal
entry.summary: Instead, FIFA Senior Vice President Issa Hayatou of Cameroon, the head of African soccer's governing body, handed the trophy to U.S. veterans Abby Wambach and Christie Rampone.

entry.title: In wake of FIFA scandal, CONCACAF proposes rules to rebuild trust
entry.summary: Plunged into crisis by a second FIFA bribery scandal in four years, the CONCACAF soccer body wants to pass sweeping new leadership rules to help rebuild.

entry.title: World Cup moments distanced women from FIFA scandal
entry.summary: For a few moments over the past month, the Women's World Cup seemed to push aside the FIFA scandal that is simmering a half planet away.

entry.title: World Cup moments distanced women from FIFA scandal
entry.summary: For FIFA, it's back to reality.

entry.title: FIFA bans former 2018-2022 WCup inspector for 7 years
entry.summary: FIFA ethics judge Joachim Eckert chaired the panel which conducted a personal hearing for Mayne-Nicholls.

entry.title: FIFA bans former 2018-2022 WCup inspector for 7 years
entry.summary:
The official chosen by FIFA to inspect 2018 and 2022 World Cup hosting candidates was banned from soccer for seven years on Monday for breaking ethics rules.

FIFA's ethics committee gave no reason for its decision to suspend Harold Mayne-Nicholls, a former president of Chile's football federation who is disputing the sanction.

entry.title: FIFA bans former 2018-2022 WCup inspector for 7 years
entry.summary: Mayne-Nicholls was appointed by FIFA in 2010 to lead a six-member team evaluating the 2018-2022 World Cup bidders.

entry.title: FIFA bans World Cup bid inspector for seven years for breaking ethics rules
entry.summary: FIFA's ethics committee said Monday Mayne-Nicholls would be barred from "any kind of football-related activity at national and international level" for seven years.

entry.title: FIFA bans former 2018-2022 WCup inspector for 7 years (Yahoo Sports)
entry.summary:
Mayne-Nicholls was considering standing in the FIFA presidential election when his ethics case was reported last year.

In the technical report, Mayne-Nicholls flagged eventual winners Russia and Qatar as presenting the most risk to FIFA as potential host nations.

entry.title: FIFA issues warning to Wambach after officiating remarks
entry.summary:
FIFA has issued a warning to U.S. forward Abby Wambach for comments she made about the officiating in a match against Colombia at the Women's World Cup.

The comments concerning French referee Stephanie Frappart might have merited discipline by FIFA, soccer's international governing body.

FIFA said in a statement Thursday night that the apology factored into the decision.

The warning cited article 57 of FIFA's disciplinary code, which concerns sportsmanlike conduct.

entry.title: Blatter: French, German Presidents Tried Influence WCup Vote
entry.summary:
"I'm there now to fight. Not for myself but for FIFA," said Blatter, who added he was on the right path and had no doubts.

"Is FIFA responsible from the top down for everything in football, what happens in some village somewhere around the world?" asked Blatter, also a target of the American investigation.

"Everyone has fears, for example of death, but with regard to my work at FIFA I have no fear. I've nothing to be afraid of," said Blatter.

entry.title: Africa's soccer strongman a candidate for FIFA president?
entry.summary:
The son of a sultan from northern Cameroon, Issa Hayatou has ruled African soccer for 27 years and counting, a decade longer than Sepp Blatter has been in charge of FIFA.

Once a critical opponent of Blatter in a FIFA presidential election in 2002, Hayatou re-emerged from a resounding defeat to be a loyal lieutenant, whipping up support for the controversial FIFA president.

As senior VP, Hayatou was delegated to hand over the women's trophy in Vancouver, pushing African soccer's strongman into the spotlight at a time when FIFA is in crisis.

entry.title: Africa's soccer strongman a candidate for FIFA president?
entry.summary:
When told the FIFA election, and asked if Africa would have a candidate, he replied: "I don't know."

Hayatou's one failure, though, was the 2002 FIFA presidential election, when Blatter beat him heavily by 139 votes to 56 in a bitter contest.

With 25 years on FIFA's ruling board, Hayatou the survivor has probably learned when and when not to pick a fight.

entry.title: FIFA Deflects Criticism About Absence of Blatter From Final
entry.summary: But FIFA officials said the gap needs to close between the countries that have made serious investments in women's soccer and those that are lagging behind, creating imbalance in a tournament that expanded to 24 teams for the first time.

entry.title: FIFA deflects criticism about absence of Blatter from final
entry.summary:
While both organizations raved about the successes of the event, the absence of Blatter and Valcke because of the FIFA corruption investigation lingered.

It provided a bookend to the tournament that opened in the wake of the initial wave from the FIFA corruption investigation, but has mostly become a secondary story during the tournament, just as organizers had hoped when the event opened a month ago.

entry.title: U.S. asks Switzerland for extradition of 7 FIFA officials
entry.summary:
The seven men include FIFA vice president Jeffrey Webb of the Cayman Islands and Eugenio Figueredo of Uruguay, who was arrested two days before his FIFA vice presidential term expired.

Costa Rican soccer federation President Eduardo Li was arrested two days before he was due to formally join FIFA's executive committee.

entry.title: Swiss say US has filed formal request to extradite 7 FIFA officials arrested in May
Sepp Blatter has 'clear conscience' despite FIFA corruption probe
entry.summary: Four days after being re-elected for a fifth term, Blatter said on June 2 that he would step down amid a crisis provoked by American and Swiss federal investigations of corruption linked to FIFA.

entry.title: Blatter says he has 'clear conscience' despite FIFA probes
entry.summary: The 79-year-old told Bunte that he happily accepts "fair and constructive criticism, also to consider what can be done differently. But when someone says, 'Blatter is corrupt because FIFA is corrupt', I can only shake my head. Anyone who makes such claims without proof should be jailed."

entry.title: Sepp Blatter not going to Women's World Cup final in Canada as probes into FIFA continue
entry.summary: FIFA said "due to their current commitments in Zurich, the FIFA President and the FIFA Secretary General will remain at the FIFA Headquarters."

entry.title: FIFA's Blatter will not attend Women's World Cup final
entry.summary: FIFA president Sepp Blatter will not travel to Canada for the final of the women's World Cup on July 5 for personal reasons, a U.S.-based lawyer for Blatter said on Tuesday.

entry.title: FIFA election chief reminds Blatter of need to step down
entry.summary:
Sepp Blatter was warned from within FIFA on Sunday not to attempt to backtrack on his pledge to quit as president.

Asked on Sunday if Blatter was categorically ruling out standing in the new election, FIFA said: "We refer you to the remarks from FIFA President Blatter from 2 June. FIFA has no further comment."

entry.title: FIFA hopeful Bility says would step aside for Hayatou
entry.summary: The Liberian who wants to be FIFA president says he would step aside if longtime African soccer head Issa Hayatou decided to run.

entry.title: FIFA election monitor urges Blatter to commit to going
entry.summary: Sepp Blatter got a clear message on Sunday from FIFA election monitor Domenico Scala to end speculation he wants to stay in office.

entry.title: Former Brazil star Zico wants to run for FIFA president
entry.summary: Marin was one of seven top soccer officials arrested two weeks ago in connection with the growing bribery and corruption scandal surrounding FIFA.

entry.title: FIFA-financed movie nets only $900 in limited US release
entry.summary:
Made for about $30 million and largely bankrolled by FIFA to trumpet the soccer federation's 111-year history, "United Passions" had no expectations of drawing crowds.

But the minuscule result still was a striking repudiation of a high-priced FIFA puff piece starring Tim Roth as FIFA President Sepp Blatter, who announced last week that he will resign.

The film's U.S. release was planned months before a Justice Department investigation alleged rampant corruption throughout FIFA and indicted 14 FIFA officials and soccer marketing executives.

The movie, which also stars Gerard Depardieu as World Cup creator Jules Rimet and Sam Neill as former FIFA president Joao Havelange, gives a generally rosy view of the scandal-plagued FIFA.

"United Passions" already was a huge write down for FIFA.

entry.title: Ben Affleck to Produce FIFA Scandal Film
entry.summary: The American side of the FIFA scandal is getting the movie treatment with Ben Affleck among those bringing story to the big the screen.

entry.title: FIFA issues warning to Wambach after officiating remarks
entry.summary: "The chairman of the FIFA Disciplinary Committee took into consideration all the circumstances of the case, including the fact that Abby Wambach took full ownership and apologized for her comments in a timely manner," the statement said.

entry.title: Brazil legend Zico confirms his plans to stand in the FIFA presidency election
entry.summary: Former Brazil star Zico on Wednesday confirmed he will stand in the election to succeed Sepp Blatter as president of FIFA, although he admitted he may struggle to find enough support.

entry.title: Swiss attorney general seizes evidence from FIFA offices
entry.summary:
The Swiss federal agency says FIFA handed over seized "IT data" to its officials.

The evidence gathering follows two weeks after FIFA's offices were raided for the investigation.

entry.title: FIFA to elect Blatter successor on December 16 - BBC
entry.summary: FIFA confirmed in a statement on Wednesday that its executive committee would meet in July to pick a date for the full presidential vote, with various options set to be discussed.

entry.title: Maradona's road to FIFA presidency filled with obstacles
entry.summary: In the often mysterious world of FIFA politics, it is far from clear which five of the 209 member federations would choose to nominate Maradona and why they would do it.

entry.title: Maradona's road to FIFA presidency filled with obstacles
entry.summary: Journalist Victor Hugo Morales said on Twitter late Sunday, June 21, 2015 that Maradona plans to run for president of FIFA.

entry.title: Maradona's road to FIFA presidency filled with obstacles
entry.summary:
If Diego Maradona is serious about running for the FIFA presidency, he still has a lot of work to do just to get on the ballot.

Maradona's desire to run for FIFA's top job was reported by Victor Hugo Morales, a journalist close to the retired great.

entry.title: Diego Maradona plans run for FIFA presidency
Exclusive: Banks did not do enough to police FIFA transactions, says global agency
entry.summary:
Some European and U.S. banks had already stepped up scrutiny of FIFA-related accounts and at least one said it had stopped handling FIFA business for some time because of corruption allegations.

In a statement FATF said that "recent reports about alleged corruption and money laundering activities on a large scale by several high-ranking FIFA officials underscore how important it is that financial institutions identify and monitor high-risk customers."

"Sports associations like the International Federation of Association Football (FIFA) or the International Olympic Committee are not businesses but associations. They do not pay taxes and, as associations, are exempt from the Swiss anti-corruption legal framework," the State Department said in the report.

The involvement of anti-money-laundering monitors in current investigations of FIFA corruption was highlighted last week by Michael Lauber, attorney general of Switzerland.

entry.title: FIFA executive committee to choose election date
entry.summary: FIFA says there are "various date options" for the election.

entry.title: UEFA President Michel Platini says he won't talk about FIFA
entry.summary: PARIS (AP) " UEFA President Michel Platini met with French President Francois Hollande on Wednesday amid speculation that he will run for the FIFA presidency when Sepp Blatter follows through with his resignation.

entry.title: Obama: FIFA must be run with integrity
entry.summary: "In conversations I've had here in Europe, people think it is very important for FIFA to be able to operate with integrity and transparency and accountability," Obama told reporters at a news conference after the G7 summit.

entry.title: FIFA hands over IT data to Swiss attorney general
entry.summary: The OAG, which took data and documents from FIFA last month, will speak with Mr Blatter and other officials if they are of interest to its investigation.

entry.title: FIFA to kick off Blatter succession process in July
Bidding for 2026 World Cup to be postponed - FIFA official
entry.summary: "Due to the situation, I think it's nonsense to start any bidding process for the time being. It will be postponed," FIFA Secretary General Jerome Valcke told a news conference in the southern Russian city of Samara.

entry.title: FIFA postpones 2026 World Cup bidding amid turmoil
entry.summary:
FIFA secretary general Jerome Valcke says it would be "nonsense" to begin the process now.

FIFA planned to write to its 209 member federations this week to explain the bidding timetable and rules.

entry.title: FIFA suspends 2026 World Cup bidding amid corruption scandal
entry.summary: The host for the tornament is expected to be chosen by the 209 FIFA members in May 2017 at a meeting in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

entry.title: FIFA Women's World Cup: Nigeria's Ugo Njoku suspended 3 games
entry.summary: FIFA, soccer's international governing body, also fined Njoku.

entry.title: Blatter may seek to stay as FIFA boss, source tells Swiss paper
entry.summary: FIFA, in an emailed statement, referred Reuters to the speech Blatter made on June 2 and said they had "no further comment to make".

entry.title: Fifa boss insists Blatter must quit
entry.summary: The official overseeing the next Fifa presidential election has reminded Sepp Blatter to stick with his plans to step down.

entry.title: Blatter may seek to stay as FIFA boss, source tells Swiss paper
entry.summary: Blatter's renewed interest in the job was also a reason for the departure of Walter de Gregorio as FIFA's director of communications, since he had argued for a completely new start and advised Blatter to go, the Swiss newspaper said.

entry.title: How to fix FIFA: Experts say agency needs outside reformer
entry.summary: He said FIFA should publicize the "compensation of the president and executive committee members."

entry.title: Interpol suspends decade-long partnership with FIFA amid corruption investigations
entry.summary: Interpol secretary general Jurgen Stock said: 'In light of the current context surrounding FIFA, while Interpol is still committed to developing our Integrity in Sport programme, I have decided to suspend the agreement.

entry.title: Interpol ditches FIFA deal as corruption scandal deepens
entry.summary: Interpol's decision was a disappointment, FIFA said, since the 2011 "integrity in sport" program was not connected to the "current issues" it faced.

entry.title: EU parliament urges Blatter to quit FIFA immediately
entry.summary:
The European Parliament said Blatter's failure to depart immediately would block efforts to rid FIFA of rampant corruption.

The soap opera at FIFA took another turn when it announced that De Gregorio was leaving two days after making a joke at FIFA's expense on a Swiss chat show.

"The FIFA president, secretary-general and media director are sitting in a car. Who's driving. Answer? The police," De Gregorio said.

A FIFA statement gave no reason for De Gregorio leaving what had become an increasingly thankless job of defending FIFA during the scandal.

entry.title: Argentines wanted in FIFA case ask to remain free
entry.summary: Two Argentine businessmen wanted in a FIFA bribery investigation are petitioning an appeals court to remain free while officials consider U.S. requests for their extradition.

entry.title: FIFA's top spokesman leaves job, Blatter urged to do same
entry.summary: Still, Blatter praised FIFA's handling of the ongoing corruption crisis in the organization's in-house magazine.

entry.title: FIFA's top spokesman leaves job, Blatter urged to do same
entry.summary: FIFA responded by announcing that its executive committee will meet on July 20 in Zurich to decide when from December to February the election to decide Blatter's successor should be held.

entry.title: FIFA's top spokesman leaves job, Blatter urged to do same
entry.summary: Soccer governing body FIFA said Thursday, June 11, 2015 that its director of public affairs Walter De Gregorio is leaving with immediate effect.

entry.title: FIFA's top spokesman leaves job, Blatter urged to do same
entry.summary:
GENEVA (AP) " FIFA's top spokesman left his job Thursday, hours after Sepp Blatter was urged to do the same by the European Parliament.

Schawinski closed the show by asking De Gregorio to tell his favorite joke about FIFA.

De Gregorio set up the punchline by saying the FIFA president, himself and secretary general Jerome Valcke were in a car, so who was driving?

FIFA announced the exit of De Gregorio in a terse statement that did not have comment from the president or his spokesman.

FIFA said De Gregorio "would be retained as a consultant until the end of the year."

entry.title: FIFA's top spokesman leaves his job as European lawmakers urge Sepp Blatter to do the same
entry.summary: FIFA communications director Walter De Gregorio, closely tied to the embattled FIFA president since 2011, left his job three days after telling a joke about soccer's governing body on a TV talk show.

entry.title: FIFA spokesman De Gregorio steps down
entry.summary:
FIFA said De Gregorio's deputy, Nicolas Maingot, will step up to the director's position.

"Walter has worked incredibly hard for the past four years and we are immensely grateful for all he has done. I am glad we will be able to continue to draw on his expertise until the end of the year," FIFA secretary general Jerome Valcke said.

entry.title: EU lawmakers urge FIFA's Blatter to go now
entry.summary: "The European Parliament... therefore calls on FIFA to select, in a transparent and inclusive way, an appropriate interim leader to replace Joseph Blatter forthwith."

entry.title: European lawmakers urge FIFA president Blatter to go now
entry.summary:
STRASBOURG, France (AP) - European lawmakers have urged FIFA President Sepp Blatter to step down immediately, and for an interim leader to be appointed.

FIFA is not obliged to heed the parliament and has previously dismissed calls for action made by lawmaker groups, including the Council of Europe.

entry.title: Analysis - FIFA to hold new election but concerns it under old rules
entry.summary:
LAUSANNE, Switzerland (Reuters) - FIFA began the process of finding a replacement for outgoing president Sepp Blatter on Wednesday with the same system which has caused problems in the past.

On Wednesday, Switzerland's Office of the Attorney General seized further data from FIFA as part of its probe.

entry.title: FIFA to hold new election but under same old rules
entry.summary: However, the rules governing the election will remain the same as they are enshrined in the FIFA statutes and can only be changed by Congress.

entry.title: Football: Zico puts his name in the hat for Fifa President
entry.summary:
Former Brazil star Zico wants to run for the presidency of FIFA, even though he believes the odds are stacked against him being elected.

"I would like to confirm this decision about the possibility of being a candidate in the next FIFA election," Zico told a news conference in his native Rio de Janeiro.

FIFA said earlier Wednesday its executive committee would meet next month to choose an election date.

entry.title: More turmoil for FIFA and World Cup bidding contests
entry.summary: FIFA Secretary General Jerome Valcke, right, and Russian Sports Minister Vitaly Mutko, left, walk along an embankment of Volga river in Samara, Russia, Tuesday, June 9, 2015.

entry.title: Former Brazil star Zico running for FIFA president
Argentine says he won't fight extradition to face US charges in FIFA corruption case
entry.summary: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina - An Argentine businessman who was indicted by U.S. authorities in the FIFA corruption case says he is willing to be extradited to the U.S. from Italy, where he is being held.

entry.title: Argentine willing to be extradited to US in FIFA case
Trinidad AG: Gov't feared ex-FIFA VP Warner a flight risk
More turmoil for FIFA and World Cup bidding contests
entry.summary: "Today there is no leadership at FIFA so it's normal that it's been suspended," the UEFA president and former France great said at a news conference in Paris which overlapped with Valcke's in Russia.

entry.title: More turmoil for FIFA and World Cup bidding contests
entry.summary: Two weeks ago it raided FIFA offices and opened "criminal proceedings against persons unknown on suspicion of criminal mismanagement and of money laundering."

entry.title: Swiss attorney general seizes evidence from FIFA offices
FIFA to kick off Blatter succession process in July
entry.summary: FIFA secretary general Jerome Valcke said during an event in Russia that it would be "nonsense" to start the bidding process for the 2026 tournament for the time being.

entry.title: Swiss Justice Dept: 1 of 7 arrested in FIFA case seeks bail
FIFA?s search for Blatter replacement to begin in July
entry.summary: Scandal-hit FIFA will hold an extraordinary executive committee meeting in July to discuss dates for the election to replace president Sepp Blatter, who announced his resignation next week.

entry.title: FIFA postpones start of 2026 World Cup bidding amid turmoil
entry.summary: SAMARA, Russia (AP) " FIFA has suspended the 2026 World Cup bidding process amid a widening corruption scandal implicating previous bid contests.

entry.title: FIFA insists Russia, Qatar bids were fairly awarded in 2010
entry.summary: "It didn't transgress any FIFA practices, any practices applicable to the bidding process. What else can we say?"

entry.title: FIFA suspect Burzaco turns himself in to Italian police
entry.summary: Burzaco, who was indicted by U.S. authorities in connection to the FIFA corruption case, is currently in a jail cell pending a hearing later Tuesday on whether to confirm the arrest, as is procedure in Italy.

entry.title: FIFA scandal: Alejandro Burzaco turns himself into police
entry.summary: In a separate Swiss investigation, authorities seized documents at FIFA headquarters in their probe into the bidding contests for the 2018 and 2022 World Cup tournaments.

entry.title: FIFA Suspect Burzaco Turns Himself in to Italian Police
entry.summary:
Burzaco was named on Interpol's most wanted list last Wednesday, along with five other men with ties to FIFA.

Leoz, a former FIFA executive committee member who is under house arrest in Paraguay, was also named on the Interpol list, as was FIFA vice president Jack Warner and Jose Margulies, a Brazilian broadcast executive.

entry.title: Argentine sought by U.S. in FIFA scandal surrenders in Italy
entry.summary: ROME (Reuters) - Businessman Alejandro Burzaco, one of three Argentines wanted by U.S. authorities over the FIFA bribery investigation, surrendered voluntarily to police in northern Italy on Tuesday.

entry.title: FIFA suspect Burzaco turns himself in to Italian police
entry.summary: MILAN (AP) " An Argentine businessman who was indicted by U.S. authorities in connection to the FIFA corruption case turned himself in to Italian police on Tuesday.

entry.title: FIFA suspect Burzaco turns himself in to Italian police
FIFA-financed movie nets only $900 in limited US release
Bach: FIFA must go through 'painful experience' to reform
entry.summary:
Bach gave his most extensive comments to date on the bribery allegations engulfing FIFA, a far-reaching scandal that led Sepp Blatter to resign as president last week pending new elections.

Bach said the size of the FIFA scandal was much bigger than the case that led to the ouster of 10 IOC members for accepting improper inducements during Salt Lake's winning bid for the 2002 Winter Games.

entry.title: Obama: Soccer fans want FIFA to operate with integrity
entry.summary: He says in conversations with people in Europe, he's heard concerns about the importance of FIFA operating with transparency and accountability.

entry.title: Obama: Soccer fans want FIFA to operate with integrity
entry.summary: Obama weighed in on the FIFA corruption scandal during a visit to Germany.

entry.title: Obama: Soccer fans want FIFA to operate with integrity
entry.summary: ELMAU, Germany (AP) " President Barack Obama says soccer fans around the world want to ensure FIFA operates with integrity.

entry.title: Bach warns FIFA that reforms will be painful
entry.summary: Bach added that he did not want to give advice to FIFA and pointed out that the structures of the two organisations were enormously different and difficult to compare.

entry.title: Bach warns FIFA that reforms will be painful
entry.summary:
"We can only encourage FIFA to continue (with) the reforms which have been initiated, we cannot give detailed advice of what to do but we appreciate there is a readiness for reforms," he told a news conference.

"The structure of FIFA is very different from the IOC and the difference in the scope is huge. There is almost no comparison of what happened with Salt Lake City and what is now at stake with regards to FIFA," said Bach.

entry.title: John Oliver keeps FIFA promise, chugs Bud Light Lime on show
